He co-directs theperformance company madhause with Ben Evansand is part of the Portland-based performancesupport group Physical Education (P.E.) withAllie Hankins, keyon gaskin, and Lu Yim.Throwing the Bouquet: Part OneMeasured on a shelf, the full run of Contact Quarterly's printissues--from Vol. 1#1, published in April 1975, through thelast issue, Vol. 44#2, Summer/Fall 2019--amounts to a neat 23.75inches wide.In my imagination, I throw them all up in the air at once, seeingeach individual page, article, sentence, thought, author, dance,drawing, comma deliberation, press run, printer, subscriber--allof it--flying up and apart. It's as if the pressure of holding thesedynamic experiences, flattened together between two covers,standing side by side on a shelf, has finally reached its limit, acritical mass that must explode, transform into another medium,another state.I follow the fountain of pages, CQ 's ultimately untrackable holographicdissemination of embodied dance practice and discovery over thelast 45 years, as the issues unbind and spread out. The aeration isa relief. The dances hover, shimmer, and shift. Gravity hasn't yettaken hold of the bits and brought them back down to earth. Maybeit never will. Maybe new forces are at work here, conditions thatdon't yet have names but do have influence. Maybe our next danceforms, creations, revelations, practices, collaborations, improvisations,breathe a different kind of air, travel best through materials and mediawe haven't yet considered, invented, discovered, or recognized.What you hold in your hands is CQ 's last print periodical publication.Hold it tight. Hold it loose. Savor it. Celebrate its unique 45-year run,in which you have actually played a significant part. Now set it downgently--or enjoy a good hard dash of it to the ground, or just let itfall from your hands and watch gravity take it down. And then comewith us as we shift our editorial weight to CQ Unbound , our year-roundonline publication, and to whatever other adventures come next.In this moment I can feel the familiar thrill of making somethingunfamiliar, the awkwardness and fear and promise of uncertainty,the suspension of belief that allows a new thing to arise, to berecognized and welcomed. We're walking the improvisational talkas we enter this new unknown.I stand in awe of this change. I shift my weight from leg to leg,from land (print) to air (online), not yet certain of the forms thatwill arise to communicate the dancing, thinking, feeling, movementdiscovery, and experiences we will have next.My collaboration with the incomparable brilliance and particularityof Contact Quarterly/Contact Editions codirector and coeditor LisaNelson has been central to CQ over these decades. Together, wehave made manifest the very specific and circumstantial collectionof voices, images, designs, layouts, and formats necessary for CQand Contact Editions. The perpetual friction of our differences hascontinued to irritate, stimulate, and illuminate the passion we havefor encouraging and documenting the articulation of the mysteriesof the moving body. It is one of my life's most unpredictable, precious,challenging, beloved, and valued collaborations.photo by Nancy Stark SmithImprovising at the CQ office, April 2015.And then there's the essential, largely invisible team of brilliantand committed editors and designers that have made the last 20+years of issues possible. Working side by side with me every stepof the way, the designers (Lila Hurwitz, Patrick O'Rourke, and JillApolinario), associate editors (Mary Ramsay, Melinda Buckwalter,Nyx Zierhut, Aretha Aoki, Lailye Weidman, and Meredith Bove), andhardworking CI Newsletter coeditors (Cheryl Pallant, Pen Dale,Sue Lauther, Sara Zolbrod, Neige Christiansen, Dey Summer, andColleen Bartley) have bridged connections between CQ and newgenerations and communities of artists, proofread every commaon the final pages, voiced opinions about page and cover designs,and initiated and followed up on communication with authors. Forpitifully low wages, their commitment and vision have contributedmore to CQ 's legacy than could ever be measured.Right now, I'm picturing the bouquet of issues--with a strongintention of sharing the innovation and inspiration that broughtthem together--unbinding as it flies and, after a long luxurioussuspension, falling in a myriad of delightful ways into your manyunsuspecting hands.With love and profound thanks for your sustained trust andcreative engagement with CQ now, in years past, and in theunknowable and thus infinitely possible future, where ourdancing bodies and minds will continue to meet.Nancy Stark SmithP.S. Part 2 of Throwing the Bouquet (and the original impetusfor that title)--a passing of the Contact Improvisation archivalbaton--will jump the frame of this Note, crossing the bridge toCQ 's online home, CQ Unbound . Read more on our website:Moving Ideas--Physical and Virtual Spaces:CQ & Me & CQ and...I first heard about CQ from Leah Stein in 1994, as anundergraduate student at Swarthmore College [in Swarth-more, PA] when she encouraged us to submit our writingsabout our experiences with CI. It felt exciting to me thata publication would want to hear from college students.I didn't submit in the end, but it was my first exposureto the journal, and I thoroughly enjoyed the articles andespecially the ads and that it was artist led. I noticed theContacts listings in the back of people to reach out towhen traveling, which I did at times.My second significant experience with CQ was in2005, when CQ coeditor Melinda Buckwalter invitedme to write about my project Artifacts of the Ephemeral,which was a residency and installation that took place atChisenhale Dance Space in London, England. The finalarticle, A Moving Installation, appeared in the Place2 issue,CQ Vol. 32.1, Winter/Spring 2007. I was flattered that theeditors wanted to hear about my small project when therewere other, more established artists, and I was also (andstill am) blown away by the attention that the editorialteam gave me in the process of articulating my ideas, theirdesire to understand my practice, and the commitment tohave the writing reflect that, to include details of the feltsense even down to the title.My relationship with CQ changed dramatically whenNancy Stark Smith asked me to be guest coeditor with herof the CQ CI Newsletter in 2012. Our first Skype call wasover six hours long, going over the ins and outs of makingonline and print versions, including photo captions andcredits. We haven't stopped coediting the Newsletter since,and it has developed over the past seven years of our worktogether. The articles have grown in their scope and length.We've improved systems that enable us to edit live onlineand to work remotely. I've had the pleasure to work withVideo still of Colleen Bartley in Walk on Blue, filmed by Richard Bleasdalein 2000 and used as part of Bartley's Meditations on Vulnerability, 2018.the writing from more than 200 authors from about 30countries about their CI practice.It has been a labor of love and a pleasure to workwith dancers and teachers from all over the world who areenthusiastic about CI. I have received an education aboutpublishing, translating, and ways of working with peopleto craft their language (in English) to describe and sharetheir dance practice.I'd like to bookend this story by mentioning my latestperformance at Chisenhale Dance Space in November2018, Meditations on Vulnerability. It is directly related toCQ. I say this because Chisenhale is an artist-led projectthat is about the same age as CQ. It's the place that hasbeen a home to my eclectic practice and has a kinshipwith CI; after Dartington College, Chisenhale is the placein the UK where CI was practiced most abundantly in itsearly years and it supported New Dance and had its ownpublication. It also relates to the approach I take as aneditor, which is directly related to my creative practiceand my experience of living in the world with a humanbody, its form, and its vulnerabilities. Both are artist-ledprojects and both have been a home base for me becauseof a common ethos of curiosity. As an editor, the authorstake the lead and my role is to listen and reflect back andhelp them articulate their ideas in their own unique way.What First Rule of CI?There have been several articles about Contact Improvisa-tion in recent CQs with prominent references to the FirstRule of Contact Improvisation,* most recently How theFirst Rule Brought #MeToo to Contact Improvisation byMichele Beaulieux, CQ Vol. 44.1, Winter/Spring 2019, aswell as Martin Keogh's mention of it in previous CQ articlesand now his book, Dancing Deeper Still. In each case, I havewanted to pipe up to either edit these mentions or footnotethem with my own opinion, but I resisted, as it felt like aninappropriate use of my editorial power with CQ. It isonly now that I have finally taken the time and page spaceto respond. [N.S.S.]*From Richard Kim's blog post: Rules: It's called the FirstRule of CI, or the Only Rule, or...maybe the FundamentalPrinciple. Its shorthand version is 'take care of yourself,' butI've heard it expressed as, 'Above all else, you are responsiblefor yourself.'In my experience as a member of the first grouppracticing Contact Improvisation with Steve Paxton in1972, the original training for Contact and the foundationfor the early years of its development encouraged both anawareness of our own limits and (mostly physical) safety,and, an awareness of those around us. This emphasis onawareness and safety for all continues to be at the founda-tion of my own practice and teaching of CI. The idea oftaking care of yourself--in other words, of dancing withawareness so as to work within your limits (howeverdrawing by Neca Zarvosyou perceive them)--was never a call to be only, or evenprimarily, concerned with one's own safety and well-being.We were always looking out for each other.It seems that perhaps the telephone game phenom-enon is at work here. Apparently some people who heardthe initial suggestion in early CI classes to take care ofyourself and those around you (through the use of periph-eral vision, etc.) were so happy to be given permission toprioritize taking care of themselves that the second half ofthat suggestion/principle withered on the vine. Eventually,it seems, the suggestion was further reduced to take careof yourself first (and foremost) and achieved First Rule ofCI status. Ouch! This hurts me every time I hear it.I wonder when this term first rule emerged. Itcertainly was not there in the first years of CI. Therewere no explicit rules as far as I remember--only anatmosphere and practice of encouraging mutual safety,support, and discovery. (And the suggestion to put onefoot back when catching a hurtling body so you couldspiral on the way down and not just be knocked over.)When I recently brought up this first rule phenome-non with first generation CI dancer Nita Little, she wasstunned and said she had never heard the term before.So I think it's fair to say that this construction is a morerecent invention. It was not there from the beginning,as is regularly implied in exchanges on social media andin writing that I've seen. Exactly when it began, I don'tknow. Although it seems pervasive now among many CIpractitioners and communities, I think it might be usefulfor CI researchers, teachers, and practitioners to knowthat it was not part of the foundation of the work.The phenomenon of this kind of reduction ofvalues, intentions, and suggestions into inaccurate andall-too-solid dogmas and rules is a compelling, albeitdisconcerting, study.I am grateful to feel the current questioning anddiscussion concerning this important but apparentlymisunderstood, misnamed, and misused principle: whichwas, and is, for me always about taking care to dance insuch a way as to not injure yourself or others.I set out to construct a timeline of my involvement withcontact improvisation and Contact Quarterly and was,needless to say, extremely grateful to own an almostcomplete set of back issues--because at my advanced age,I discover that though I can recall places and dates, I amlosing my memory for names. Herewith, what I was ableto pull together:1975: A fledgling dance critic for the Canadian Broadcast-ing Corporation, I'm invited to show up at the VancouverOpera Association for what turns out to be Steve Paxtonand Nancy Stark Smith's first performance of ContactImprovisation in Vancouver, BC. This encounter utterlyupends my sense of what dance might be.1977: I enroll in workshops at Vancouver's Western Front,where I study CI with members of ReUnion (Steve, Nancy,Nita Little, and Curt Siddall), and Mangrove (Curt, ByronBrown, John LeFan, and James Tyler). My first effort atwriting about Contact, broadcast on the CBC in June, istranscribed and reprinted in an early issue of the ContactNewsletter. Later, I travel to Berkeley for the July Projectin the Moving Arts, an intensive involvement with Curt,James, Terry Sendgraff, and Ruth Zaporah.1979: Having moved back to New York and taken a jobrunning the American Dance Guild, I use my vacation toreturn to Vancouver for Current Exchange, a gathering ofexperienced contactors led by Steve and including a veryyoung Stephen Petronio. He heads for New York and a jobas the first male in the Trisha Brown Dance Company.The idea emerges to make improvisation the focus ofthe Guild's next annual meeting...1980...to be held in Minneapolis, Minnesota, in June,with Steve as the keynote speaker; Anna Halprin as theguest of honor; and practically every contact dancer onthe continent involved in a teaching capacity. We call itDance as Art Sport, after a remark by Simone Forti.1982: In a CI class in Manhattan, I tumble off Petronio'sback and bruise my coccyx, convincing myself that it'stime to let this practice go. But by then I've been draftedonto the board of Contact Collaborations, Inc.; I find,tucked in with the back issues, copies of minutes ofboard meetings and a draft book proposal for a fieldguide to contact improvisation, which never material-ized; Cynthia Novack's 1990 Sharing the Dance and other,later treatises--and of course, CQ itself--filled this need.)Novack died in 1996. As I page through my hugecollection of back issues, I become aware of how many ofour colleagues are gone, including James Tyler, my collegeclassmate; dancer and teacher Nancy Topf; choreographerTrisha Brown; and countless dancers and writers whowrote to and in CQ. I was rarely one of those writers, asmy economic situation made it necessary to be paid formy work.From its photocopied beginnings, the magazine grewthicker, fancier, less frequent, but has always been full ofinvaluable material from across the world. Now, in 2019,we bid farewell to this print edition of CQ, as we have toso many other publications. Though I love paging throughold paper copies, digital materials are much more easilysearchable and more widely, quickly, and inexpensivelydistributed. CQ is dead; long live CQ--and the generationsof thinkers, doers, and writers who've contributed to thisunique chronicle.With thanks to Nancy, Lisa Nelson, Steve, and all the restof the crew,In celebration of the digital adventure--CQ becomesaccessible? It is really a new adventure to try and promoteCQ to new readers.Touchdown Dance (TD), a unique company foundedin 1986 at Dartington College in Devon, UK, by Steve Paxtonand Anne Kilcoyne, grew from an idea of Steve's to bringtogether visually impaired and sighted people in theContact Improvisation (CI) experience. It appeared that atouch-based movement method would be of use to touch-based navigators in the world, and an accessible means tobring diverse bodies together. Something extraordinary isseeded by the very idea of CI, and new movement evolves,shapes itself into form spontaneously--like a choreographyof presence, of pause in motion. TD grew into a ground-breaking experience that people travel far and wide to do.Steve and Anne's article on TD [Common Sense]was one of a wave of initiatives that were written about forthe first time in a substantial way in CQ in your Dancingwith Different Populations issue in 1992 [CQ Vol. 17.1].The world of somatic practices, improvised scores, andCI-based methods have been the foundation to Touchdown'sperformances since 1992. Currently, Touchdown Dancehas three visually impaired and two sighted dancersmaking work, dancing CI, and improvising whilst teach-ing around the UK and internationally. We created aneducation pack in which the CI methods and legacy ofSteve and Anne are relayed in word and image to informcommunity and education settings in which we work.We are avid readers and supporters of CQ--and feelrelieved, as it goes digital, that it will be more accessibleto screen reader software and saving trees!!Katy Dymoke; Manchester, UKArtistic director, Touchdown Dance (since 1994)Dear CQ,The transference of movement information through theglobal contact improvisation community--an example:We were fortunate to have a copy of Contact Quarterly,Summer/Fall 2000 (Vol. 25.2), passed on from an elderteacher who had two copies--shared with her keenand developing CI dancer friends in Newcastle, a smallContact community three hours north of Sydney.The article Spacewalk--Reflections on Nancy Topf'sSpacewalk Improvisation was read and reflected on. Howtragically this woman died and yet how wonderful thatshe lives on through her work then and now. Excerptswere read to our dance improvisation collective, andthe exercise interpreted and performed. So playful anddynamic. Thanks, Nancy. And thanks Contact Quarterly.Definitely a journal for moving ideas!Even though it is only the paper version of CQ we aresaying goodbye to, it is still a heart-wrenching goodbyeto the physical, holdable, lie-on-your-bedside-table-able,put-in-your-bag-able, loanable, savorable version of themagazine that has given me, for forty-odd years, a greatbeing to belong to, whose wise, laughing, listening, andloving arms reach around the globe.Even though the online version thrives, lives on,goes out even farther and wider than the beloved paperone, I feel a loss, and a need to express my gratitude forall the years and all the labor that went into making it,sacrificing personal creative time for the benefit of thecollective.Nancy and Lisa, Melinda and all the fabulousassistant and guest editors, designers, and staff over theyears, you have been for me the roots of a magnificent tree,nourishing all of us who wanted to exchange our stories,news, and ideas, add our leaf, our flower, our pine coneloaded with winged seeds, in hopes that the winds mightcarry our feelings far. You gave us access to those winds,lifting us all into the sky on such far-reaching branches,giving all that such great beings give: inspiration, nourish-ment, shelter in the storm, and the very air we breathe. Iam a leaf on that tree, and there is not even a way for meto imagine my life without you.At the Somatics Festival 2019 in Northampton, MA, inSeptember--celebrating the work of Janet Adler, BonnieBainbridge Cohen, Nancy Stark Smith, and the 45-yearHeritage of Contact Quarterly--I sat on a panel titledArchiving the Experience of the Body in Motion withseveral distinguished archive curators.As editor of Currents Journal of the Body-MindCentering Association and Lost & Found: The CUNYPoetics Document Initiative, I felt ready to speak tobeing immersed in people's archives--my grandmother'sbuttons, my father's papers, and, later, the NYC municipalarchives in search of archaeological sites. But it wasn'tuntil I studied Body-Mind Centering that I was able toaccount for my own body and dig back to my earliesttraining, the Rhythms Fundamentals (of Ruth Doing)--a vital, but rare artifact of the American PhysicalCulture Movement.During the panel's closing, Nancy Stark Smithasked how to create an archive that was active, how totranslate experience into language and then open it backinto experience. I get it--the dancer's archive interlopeswith the reader/mover by matter of both light (film) andlanguage (scores, writings, techniques), but dance iscommunal; therefore, even the soloist is derivative from aprevious form or technique. Example: I am currently cata-loguing Bonnie Bainbridge Cohen's papers (1970-present)bound for their archival home. But does the founder's workstand alone? At this panel, Cohen said, This work wascreated in community. She wonders how to house a50-year dialogue that evolved Body-Mind Centering?Librarians and academics must take into account thenature of the bodies of the archive. It becomes a place thatstrikes us in situ and in choir. The archive is an emotionaland tactile experience not unlike the contact improvisa-tion-feeling of profundity of weight, matter, and current(flow). As Nancy put it, the translation of the languageback into experience, and, in Bonnie's words, the work...in community. I call it summoning the interface.Shall we enter the bodies of the archive from theperspective of the mover as well as the language of themovement? Finally, there ought to be a way to fashion amover's papers with enough interface as to allow forour touch.Kate Tarlow Morgan, MA, RSME;Marlboro, VermontI'm mourning the last of CQ's classy print periodicals.Congratulations and best wishes for CQ Unbound (greatname!). With gratitude and love,Aileen Crow was a beloved teacher and prolific somaticresearcher who combined her study and practice of manytechniques and philosophies of movement, creativity, andhealing to transform the lives of her students, colleagues,and anyone who came in contact with her and her work.A Laban Movement Analyst, teacher of the AlexanderTechnique since 1969, and practitioner of Neuro-Linguis-tic Programming, Aileen brought together AuthenticMovement, Mindell's Dreambody Process Work, and amultitude of other bodywork, therapeutic, movement,and creative disciplines to guide people into movement,creativity, and wellness.Her clear writings, playful character drawings,and illuminating insights contributed lucid, embodiedresearch to Contact Quarterly.Paula Sager, cofounding editor of A Moving Journal,writes, Aileen had an eye for rogue movement patterns--the odder the better--and an ear for the unspoken word,the invisible sound. She had a nose for the best of eachmodality she mastered and an unparallel appetite forunfolding process. She was a big-hearted, rebel-mindedcontributing editor for A Moving Journal, engaging con-tinuous, dynamic research and dialogue in the field ofAuthentic Movement.Aileen lived in New City, NY, and was 93 whenshe passed away on April 13, 2019. In additionto CQ's back issues (searchable on our website),Aileen's writings Janis Claxton--an Australian dancer based in Bristol,UK, and then Edinburgh, Scotland--began her artisticand teaching practice with the health and wellness of thebody. Her work shows how art is health and health is artand that art should be enlivening, nourishing, and healing.Her key ideas about relating in contact improvisation wereanchored in a keen sense of somatic health, informed byher deep understanding of the Erick Hawkins work.In leading contact improvisation workshops suchas Dancing in and out of Contact and Returning Hometo the Body, Janis emphasized self-sensing, internalphysics in relation to environment, and detailed alignmentto facilitate students' precise, expressive, and highlytuned dancing. She was highly perceptive and insightfulwith regard to stuck points in one's dancing. Whileworkshopping a skill having to do with partnering, shewould often stop and take us to the floor or to the wallto investigate our own patterning. Working on patternsto release and align the body led to openings and under-standings in the physical, emotional, and mindful aspectsof dancing--often leading to a deeper sense of creativityand self knowledge. Janis was a powerful teacher whocould quickly bring students to their inner truths andto the heart of the matter.Erick Hawkins was a profound inspiration for Janis,and she credits him with the initiation of somatic investiga-tion in the field of modern dance. Janis herself was a tirelessadvocate for healthy dance practice, somatic intelligence,and women in dance. She was strongly critical of thetrends toward extreme bodies in performance. In ourlast conversation, she was enthusiastically checking myfeminist outlook, sharpening my critical thinking, andsharing her amazing energy and insight! I am so gratefulfor her work, artistry, making, and teaching.Tamara Ashley, UKRobin MacRostieApril 16, 1945-September 29, 2019An active and beloved member of the Western Massachusettsarts community, Robin MacRostie brought her creativespirit and passion for dance to everything she did. A long-time member of Dance Generators, an intergenerationaldance company, she was involved in many aspects of artsand activism, and was well-known for her inventive,imaginative approach to problem-solving and communityaction. In addition to studying and performing dance foralmost seven decades, she held a wide range of roles inthe field, including graphic designer, costume designer,dance teacher, and choreographer for all ages, reflectingher vigorous commitment to art making and to hercommunities. Among her many contributions was theestablishment of PreClassic Dance for Children andPanValley Dance, a program to teach and perform IsadoraDuncan dance technique. In 2016, Robin worked at ContactQuarterly as a volunteer, developing the database forContact Quarterly's big library of books and periodicals,which is still in use.
